title: Model-market fit: the missing prerequisite AI founders ignore
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-22, Reading time: 15 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.nicolasbustamante.com%2Fp%2Fmodel-market-fit%3Futm_source=tldrfintech/1/0100019be6085554-3c9fa8b2-8f78-48a8-8533-cb635a34f87b-000000/pJb49hxukkIgwj9UrzdoATHu6BZX1fi5rn0kX20Fdz0=441
summary: Model-market fit: the missing prerequisite AI founders ignore (15 minute read) Before product-market fit can exist in AI, the underlying model must be capable of reliably performing the tasks customers actually need done, a threshold known as model-market fit (MMF). Markets only “explode” once model capability crosses a hard accuracy and autonomy threshold. Many AI startups fail not on distribution or UX, but because the model simply isn't ready yet.

title: AI and jobs: The decline started before ChatGPT
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-22, Reading time: 10 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fengineeringprompts.substack.com%2Fp%2Fai-and-jobs-the-decline-started-before%3Futm_source=tldrfintech/1/0100019be6085554-3c9fa8b2-8f78-48a8-8533-cb635a34f87b-000000/uNWGYMr2oGfEikTQA8UgfvBtiSGKJO8HECOqnuU3HEE=441
summary: AI and jobs: The decline started before ChatGPT (10 minute read) A new analysis challenges the claim that ChatGPT caused a sharp drop in entry-level jobs, showing that hiring in AI-exposed roles began declining months before ChatGPT launched. The timing lines up far more closely with aggressive interest rate hikes starting in early 2022, and similar patterns appeared during COVID, suggesting macroeconomic forces, not AI automation, are the primary driver so far.

title: SDFlgs - The Log Field I'd Been Ignoring That Unlocked Attack Path Detection
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-22, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.huntress.com%2Fblog%2Fldap-active-directory-detection-part-three%3Futm_source=tldrinfosec/1/0100019be619f6bb-d58c16ae-c07d-4029-84c5-a5571612f3dc-000000/gbzvY47fnez-2Y0h-THFsjLlZYwDJTfQUt70WUyQpQE=441
summary: SDFlgs - The Log Field I'd Been Ignoring That Unlocked Attack Path Detection (8 minute read) SDFlags is a field that controls which security descriptor information is returned in queries and is used extensively in BloodHound and SharpHound. Querying for nTSecurityDescriptor fields (Owner, Group, DACL, or SACL) opens the door to attack path mapping. Conversely, legitimate tools almost never set SDFlags when running AD queries, opening up a new detection opportunity.

summary: Scaling PostgreSQL to power 800 million ChatGPT users (14 minute read) OpenAI scaled PostgreSQL to support 800 million ChatGPT users and millions of queries per second for its predominantly read-heavy workloads. Their architecture uses a single primary Azure PostgreSQL instance and nearly 50 global read replicas.

title: Keeping 20,000 GPUs healthy

summary: Keeping 20,000 GPUs healthy (11 minute read) Modal runs a globally distributed pool of over 20,000 GPUs across multiple cloud providers. Its approach begins with instance type testing and selection, evaluating performance and reliability differences between cloud hyperscalers. Throughout an instance's life, Modal performs continuous passive and active healthchecking.

title: The Context Collapse Problem
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-23, Reading time: 11 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fcodegood.co%2Fwriting%2Fcontext-collapse-problem%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019beac2a03d-f4864457-9a83-4365-bf24-2e78ef1288cc-000000/ak3az0d5eZoNhvpfxqoKY9rgzFIz98AKtNQrE0wFP2U=441
summary: The Context Collapse Problem (11 minute read) AI coding assistants deliver productivity gains on new projects but underperform on legacy codebases, a "context collapse problem" caused by the invisibility of institutional knowledge and historical decisions. summary: E-commerce tip: Win back lost customers after cancelled orders (1 minute read) After a customer has refunded or cancelled an order, send a survey email asking for the reason. From that, create a Cancelled/Refunded Order Winback Flow with personalized emails based on the survey answer they selected.

A proposed fix is pay-per-use AI, with source citations and revenue sharing, so creators, users, and AI companies all benefit.

title: How Binary Dependencies Work Across Different Languages
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-23, Reading time: 13 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fvlad.website%2Fhow-binary-dependencies-work%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/0100019bead24678-cc5db18d-2a26-4123-83e1-84f2d9c282b0-000000/zBGPFifr_-U1OHHa93g6dEBe-ly0uwYGazgexUngq4Y=441
summary: How Binary Dependencies Work Across Different Languages (13 minute read) Precompiled binary libraries can be called from higher-level languages through three main approaches: dynamic linking, dynamic loading via FFI, and dynamic linking using extension modules. These techniques differ in when symbol resolution happens and how data is converted, with extension modules offering the best performance and flexibility at the cost of more complex native code.

title: Compiling Scheme to WebAssembly
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-23, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Feli.thegreenplace.net%2F2026%2Fcompiling-scheme-to-webassembly%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/0100019bead24678-cc5db18d-2a26-4123-83e1-84f2d9c282b0-000000/EZ8oRjYdAlLo6L9HfdkcWC2M7ZWzxMiKwW2Jl2TYKYs=441
summary: Compiling Scheme to WebAssembly (5 minute read) The Bob Scheme project was extended with a new compiler that lowers full Scheme directly to WebAssembly, using the WASM GC extension to support closures, cons cells, symbols, and garbage collection. The work highlights practical design choices—GC-managed structs, unboxed integers, manual string handling in linear memory, and core builtins like write implemented in raw WASM text—showing how a real high-level language can target WASM.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-23, Reading time: 11 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinks.tldrnewsletter.com%2FX1rlZU/1/0100019beb042bca-e83e8e8c-00ef-4ce4-a1cb-f741abefe227-000000/xP5e5fQouE5LfIdGOxd5VyY52yxut4n3pDHGx7ccDFA=441
summary: Against cleverness (11 minute read) As AI and other complex technologies spread, good design must focus on resilience, transparency, and recovery rather than blaming individuals or chasing peak performance. AI amplifies latent errors, deskills humans, and fails unpredictably, so systems should limit autonomy, preserve human accountability, define clear boundaries, and be designed to fail safely—aiming not for smarter systems, but wiser ones that understand their limits.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-23, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fdeepmind.google%2Fblog%2Fd4rt-teaching-ai-to-see-the-world-in-four-dimensions%2F%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019beb380879-4a003cf1-8d94-465f-af65-ce144f7ce696-000000/EjKX-yUue8rxxpd1xGuZWXs2p2OHVcHATz7kH88NiMA=441
summary: D4RT: Unified, Fast 4D Scene Reconstruction & Tracking (3 minute read) D4RT is a unified AI model for efficient 4D scene reconstruction and tracking that achieves up to 300x efficiency over traditional methods. Utilizing a unified encoder-decoder Transformer architecture, D4RT processes scenes dynamically by answering targeted queries about 3D space and time from 2D video inputs. This speed and scalability suit applications in robotics and augmented reality.

title: How I Reduced AI Token Costs by 91% with Semantic Tool Selection and Redis
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-26, Reading time: 11 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fmlops.community%2Fhow-i-reduced-ai-token-costs-by-91-with-semantic-tool-selection-and-redis%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019bf9fd83fc-7b7b43b2-9d54-41ed-864a-7e5802f55166-000000/Pgnn0qUyV48dWx-LdEYhrZacKm_caykjOEQRPlGWfYk=441
summary: How I Reduced AI Token Costs by 91% with Semantic Tool Selection and Redis (11 minute read) An enterprise AI platform eliminated the need to include all 70+ tool definitions in every LLM prompt by using multi-component embeddings stored in Redis and selecting only the 2–5 most relevant tools per query. This reduced input tokens by 91.5%, cut total costs by ~49%, boosted precision@3 to 95%, and improved response times by 31%.

title: Sirius
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-26, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fsirius-db%2Fsirius%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019bf9fd83fc-7b7b43b2-9d54-41ed-864a-7e5802f55166-000000/hdsTuTY-vvZU_ZX7iuycF8X17bF0in325mQxzW5uemA=441
summary: Sirius (GitHub Repo) Sirius is a GPU-native SQL engine that plugs into existing query engines (currently DuckDB, with Doris “coming soon”) via Substrait, so teams can offload execution to GPUs without rewriting SQL or rebuilding the whole platform. Built on NVIDIA CUDA-X, it reports ~10x TPC-H (on SF=100) speedup at similar on-demand cost. Today, it accelerates a limited operator/type set (joins, group-bys, etc.; common scalar types) and falls back to CPU for unsupported features.

title: Introduction to PostgreSQL Indexes
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-26, Reading time: 21 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fdlt.github.io%2Fblog%2Fposts%2Fintroduction-to-postgresql-indexes%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019bfa4c672e-57951fed-f4c9-4df0-8813-18ab641d574d-000000/W-urP6aGC9KTaQTT_5YLnN66ZNHdY8YSSE2noImovHE=441
summary: Introduction to PostgreSQL Indexes (21 minute read) PostgreSQL indexes are database objects that speed up data access by allowing the system to read less from disk, mapping key values to physical row locations. While these provide speed benefits for queries, they introduce costs such as increased disk space, overhead on write operations, longer query planning times, and higher memory usage.

title: The browser is the sandbox
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-26, Reading time: 18 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Faifoc.us%2Fthe-browser-is-the-sandbox%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019bfa4c672e-57951fed-f4c9-4df0-8813-18ab641d574d-000000/FT7nnugSDOTPcisjLzVJZc24AViezyUrF71NxNob328=441
summary: The browser is the sandbox (18 minute read) The browser has potential as a secure sandbox for agentic AI tools, which automate tasks and require access to a user's local files and network. It has mechanisms for filesystem isolation, controlled network access via CSP, and secure code execution using iframes and WebAssembly. A demo project is displayed in this article that shows these capabilities.

title: AI tribalism
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-26, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fnolanlawson.com%2F2026%2F01%2F24%2Fai-tribalism%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019bfa4c672e-57951fed-f4c9-4df0-8813-18ab641d574d-000000/MhnpEaAf8tSQp7XM0cCzlc7bV2iEaWShzWAtFfspOLI=441
summary: AI tribalism (6 minute read) Discussions around LLMs have devolved into unproductive tribalism, fueled by early negative associations with tech "hucksters" and fears of job displacement. AI agents are already capable of efficient code generation, bug fixing, and addressing complex issues like security and performance. Engineers need to keep experimenting with AI to stay on top of new tooling.

summary: Stripe's Lighthouse Hiring pattern (4 minute read) Lighthouse Hiring is the idea that hiring well-connected people makes subsequent hires both easier and higher quality. This strategy isn't without its downside - it takes some nuance to deploy effectively.

title: Ancient telnet Bug Happily Hands Out root to Attackers
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-26, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.theregister.com%2F2026%2F01%2F22%2Froot_telnet_bug%2F%3Futm_source=tldrinfosec/1/0100019bfaa21f61-390f892b-d6b3-409b-b0b9-5f4587889129-000000/lE8HRsUDEhCNaLefXkbjxHQov9ofC9kKb3um3PzgAp8=441
summary: Ancient telnet Bug Happily Hands Out root to Attackers (2 minute read) A critical (CVSS 9.8) vulnerability in telnet could allow unauthenticated users to obtain root privileges on systems running InetUtils telnetd. To exploit the vulnerability, an attacker only needs to set their USER environment variable to “-f root” and pass the “-a” or “--login” flag to telnet. Experts recommend updating to the latest version of telnet or, ideally, switching to a more secure protocol such as SSH.

title: Sometimes Your Job is to Stay the Hell Out of the Way
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-27, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Frandsinrepose.com%2Farchives%2Fsometimes-your-job-is-to-stay-the-hell-out-of-the-way%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019bff5b3376-7ad66c83-8858-48d9-8a23-07bf56211163-000000/dbA90lhi14cS4QwCcO5eYsCs0JFz2PKjW0_utMIpMaU=441
summary: Sometimes Your Job is to Stay the Hell Out of the Way (6 minute read) “Wolves” are rare, highly productive engineers who autonomously tackle critical problems, driven solely by the work's importance rather than recognition. Attempts to formalize "Wolf" roles fail, as these individuals thrive only in a safe, healthy, and distraction-free engineering culture. For managers, the most effective approach is often to recognize genuine "Wolf" contributions and then "stay the hell out of the way."
